Author: Bahlmann
Citation: Bahlmann, J., Schubotz, R. I., & Friederici, A. D. (2008). Hierarchical artificial grammar processing engages Broca’s area. NeuroImage, 42(2), 525–534. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.neuroimage.2008.04.249
Contrast Name: hierachical > adjacent (grammatical only)

Author: Karuza
Citation: Karuza, E. A., Newport, E. L., Aslin, R. N., Starling, S. J., Tivarus, M. E., & Bavelier, D. (2013). The neural correlates of statistical learning in a word segmentation task: An fMRI study. Brain and Language, 127(1), 46–54. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.bandl.2012.11.007
Contrast Name: Listening to (segmentable) forward speech > Listening to (nonsegmentable) backwards speech

Author: Karuza
Citation: Karuza, E. A., Newport, E. L., Aslin, R. N., Starling, S. J., Tivarus, M. E., & Bavelier, D. (2013). The neural correlates of statistical learning in a word segmentation task: An fMRI study. Brain and Language, 127(1), 46–54. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.bandl.2012.11.007
Contrast Name: Proficiency increase for [Listening to (segmentable) forward speech > Listening to (nonsegmentable) backwards speech]

Author: Karuza
Citation: Karuza, E. A., Li, P., Weiss, D. J., Bulgarelli, F., Zinszer, B. D., & Aslin, R. N. (2016). Sampling over Nonuniform Distributions: A Neural Efficiency Account of the Primacy Effect in Statistical Learning. Journal of Cognitive Neuroscience, 28(10), 1484–1500. https://doi.org/10.1162/jocn_a_00990
Contrast Name: Main effect of task (L1+)

Author: Karuza
Citation: Karuza, E. A., Li, P., Weiss, D. J., Bulgarelli, F., Zinszer, B. D., & Aslin, R. N. (2016). Sampling over Nonuniform Distributions: A Neural Efficiency Account of the Primacy Effect in Statistical Learning. Journal of Cognitive Neuroscience, 28(10), 1484–1500. https://doi.org/10.1162/jocn_a_00990
Contrast Name: Main effect of task (L2+)

Author: Lieberman
Citation: Lieberman, M. D., Chang, G. Y., Chiao, J., Bookheimer, S. Y., & Knowlton, B. J. (2004). An Event-related fMRI Study of Artificial Grammar Learning in a Balanced Chunk Strength Design. Journal of Cognitive Neuroscience, 16(3), 427–438. https://doi.org/10.1162/089892904322926764
Contrast Name: [grammatical > non-grammatical] (includes both low and high chunk strength)

Author: McNealy
Citation: McNealy, K., Mazziotta, J. C., & Dapretto, M. (2006). Cracking the language code: Neural mechanisms underlying speech parsing. The Journal of Neuroscience: The Official Journal of the Society for Neuroscience, 26(29), 7629–7639. https://doi.org/10.1523/JNEUROSCI.5501-05.2006
Contrast Name: [AL word] > [non-word (novel trisyllabic frequency)]

Author: McNealy
Citation: McNealy, K., Mazziotta, J. C., & Dapretto, M. (2006). Cracking the language code: Neural mechanisms underlying speech parsing. The Journal of Neuroscience: The Official Journal of the Society for Neuroscience, 26(29), 7629–7639. https://doi.org/10.1523/JNEUROSCI.5501-05.2006
Contrast Name: [AL word] > [part-word (lower trisyllabic frequency)]

Author: McNealy
Citation: McNealy, K., Mazziotta, J. C., & Dapretto, M. (2006). Cracking the language code: Neural mechanisms underlying speech parsing. The Journal of Neuroscience: The Official Journal of the Society for Neuroscience, 26(29), 7629–7639. https://doi.org/10.1523/JNEUROSCI.5501-05.2006
Contrast Name: Correlation of [listening to AL stream > rest] with number of exposures.

Author: Morgan-Short
Citation: Morgan-Short, K., Deng, Z., Brill-Schuetz, K. A., Faretta-Stutenberg, M., Wong, P. C. M., & Wong, F. C. K. (2015). A view of the neural representation of second language synatx through artificial language learning under implicit contexts of exposure. Studies in Second Language Acquisition, 37(2), 383–419. https://doi.org/10.1017/S0272263115000030
Contrast Name: GJT at time 2 (high prof.) > GJT at time 1 (low prof.)

Author: Morgan-Short
Citation: Morgan-Short, K., Deng, Z., Brill-Schuetz, K. A., Faretta-Stutenberg, M., Wong, P. C. M., & Wong, F. C. K. (2015). A view of the neural representation of second language synatx through artificial language learning under implicit contexts of exposure. Studies in Second Language Acquisition, 37(2), 383–419. https://doi.org/10.1017/S0272263115000030
Contrast Name: GJT for syntactic task > GJT for control task

Author: Morgan-Short
Citation: Morgan-Short, K., Deng, Z., Brill-Schuetz, K. A., Faretta-Stutenberg, M., Wong, P. C. M., & Wong, F. C. K. (2015). A view of the neural representation of second language synatx through artificial language learning under implicit contexts of exposure. Studies in Second Language Acquisition, 37(2), 383–419. https://doi.org/10.1017/S0272263115000030
Contrast Name: [GJT at time 2 > time 1] > [baseline task at time 2 > time 1]

Author: Newman-Norland
Citation: Newman-Norlund, R. D., Frey, S. H., Petitto, L.-A., & Grafton, S. T. (2006). Anatomical Substrates of Visual and Auditory Miniature Second-language Learning. Journal of Cognitive Neuroscience, 18(12), 1984-1997.
Contrast Name: [sentence processing after grammar training > (unreported subtrahend)] > [sentence processing before grammar training > (unreported subtrahend)]; "sentence processing" = the self-paced epoch between hearing the sentence and seeing the 4 picture choices, one of which matched the grammar of the sentence.

Author: Opitz
Citation: Opitz, B., & Friederici, A. D. (2003). Interactions of the hippocampal system and the prefrontal cortex in learning language-like rules. NeuroImage, 19(4), 1730–1737. https://doi.org/10.1016/s1053-8119(03)00170-8
Contrast Name: Increase (logarithmic) in: [viewing grammatical + grammaticality judgement] > [sensorimotor control (=is it BRAD or DABA)]

Author: Ordin
Citation: Ordin, M., Polyanskaya, L., & Soto, D. (2020). Neural bases of learning and recognition of statistical regularities. Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences. https://doi.org/10.1111/nyas.14299
Contrast Name: w_acc > nonw_rej

Author: Ordin
Citation: Ordin, M., Polyanskaya, L., & Soto, D. (2020). Neural bases of learning and recognition of statistical regularities. Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences. https://doi.org/10.1111/nyas.14299
Contrast Name: w_acc > ph_rej

Author: Petersson
Citation: Petersson, K. M., Forkstam, C., & Ingvar, M. (2004). Artificial syntactic violations activate Broca’s region. Cognitive Science, 28(3), 383–407. https://doi.org/10.1207/s15516709cog2803_4
Contrast Name: [grammaticality judgement > "Is it a string of P's or L's?"]

Author: Petersson
Citation: Petersson, K. M., Forkstam, C., & Ingvar, M. (2004). Artificial syntactic violations activate Broca’s region. Cognitive Science, 28(3), 383–407. https://doi.org/10.1207/s15516709cog2803_4
Contrast Name: ([grammatical correct > grammatical incorrect] > [ungrammatical correct > ungrammatical incorrect]) = areas that show a greater difference between correct and incorrect answers for grammatical compared to ungrammatical items.

Author: Petersson
Citation: Petersson, K. M., Forkstam, C., & Ingvar, M. (2004). Artificial syntactic violations activate Broca’s region. Cognitive Science, 28(3), 383–407. https://doi.org/10.1207/s15516709cog2803_4
Contrast Name: conjunction across all subjects: ([GJT > "Is it a string of P's or L's?"] AND [correct > incorrect]) = within areas activated only while correctly performing the task, where are there significant activations for grammaticality performance over perceptual baseline?

Author: Seger
Citation: Seger, C. A., Prabhakaran, V., Poldrack, R. A., & Gabrieli, J. D. E. (2000). Neural activity differs between explicit and implicit learning of artificial grammar strings: An fMRI study. Psychobiology, 28(3), 283–292. https://doi.org/10.3758/BF03331987
Contrast Name: [Grammatical judgment] > [is TT in the string]

Author: Seger
Citation: Seger, C. A., Prabhakaran, V., Poldrack, R. A., & Gabrieli, J. D. E. (2000). Neural activity differs between explicit and implicit learning of artificial grammar strings: An fMRI study. Psychobiology, 28(3), 283–292. https://doi.org/10.3758/BF03331987
Contrast Name: [Grammatical judgment using unstudied letters] > [is DD in the string]

Author: Seger
Citation: Seger, C. A., Prabhakaran, V., Poldrack, R. A., & Gabrieli, J. D. E. (2000). Neural activity differs between explicit and implicit learning of artificial grammar strings: An fMRI study. Psychobiology, 28(3), 283–292. https://doi.org/10.3758/BF03331987
Contrast Name: [Letter string recognition] > [is there a GG in the string]

Author: Skosnik
Citation: Skosnik, P. D., Mirza, F., Gitelman, D. R., Parrish, T. B., Mesulam, M.-M., & Reber, P. J. (2002). Neural correlates of artificial grammar learning. NeuroImage, 17(3), 1306–1314. https://doi.org/10.1006/nimg.2002.1291
Contrast Name: [grammatical] > [ungrammatical]

Author: Skosnik
Citation: Skosnik, P. D., Mirza, F., Gitelman, D. R., Parrish, T. B., Mesulam, M.-M., & Reber, P. J. (2002). Neural correlates of artificial grammar learning. NeuroImage, 17(3), 1306–1314. https://doi.org/10.1006/nimg.2002.1291
Contrast Name: [grammatical judgment] > [explicit recognition of grammatical and ungrammatical letter strings]

Author: Tettamanti
Citation: Tettamanti, M., Alkadhi, H., Moro, A., Perani, D., Kollias, S., & Weniger, D. (2002). Neural Correlates for the Acquisition of Natural Language Syntax. NeuroImage, 17(2), 700–709. https://doi.org/10.1006/nimg.2002.1201
Contrast Name: [reading sentences with new syntactic rule following UG] > [reading sentences with new syntactic rule that does not follow UG]

Author: Tettamanti
Citation: Tettamanti, M., Alkadhi, H., Moro, A., Perani, D., Kollias, S., & Weniger, D. (2002). Neural Correlates for the Acquisition of Natural Language Syntax. NeuroImage, 17(2), 700–709. https://doi.org/10.1006/nimg.2002.1201
Contrast Name: [linear activation increase over time for reading sentences with new syntactic rule following UG] > [linear activation increase over time for reading sentences with new syntactic rule that does not follow UG]

Author: Turk-Browne
Citation: Turk-Browne, N. B., Scholl, B. J., Chun, M. M., & Johnson, M. K. (2009). Neural evidence of statistical learning: Efficient detection of visual regularities without awareness. Journal of Cognitive Neuroscience, 21(10), 1934–1945. https://doi.org/10.1162/jocn.2009.21131
Contrast Name: Structured > Random

Author: Yang
Citation: Yang, J., & Li, P. (2012). Brain networks of explicit and implicit learning. PloS One, 7(8), e42993. https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0042993
Contrast Name: Grammaticality judgment > fixation (explicit learners)

Author: Yang
Citation: Yang, J., & Li, P. (2012). Brain networks of explicit and implicit learning. PloS One, 7(8), e42993. https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0042993
Contrast Name: Grammaticality judgment > fixation (implicit learners)

Author: Yusa
Citation: Yusa, N., Koizumi, M., Kim, J., Kimura, N., Uchida, S., Yokoyama, S., Miura, N., Kawashima, R., & Hagiwara, H. (2011). Second-language Instinct and Instruction Effects: Nature and Nurture in Second-language Acquisition. Journal of Cognitive Neuroscience, 23(10), 2716–2730. https://doi.org/10.1162/jocn.2011.21607
Contrast Name: [Test 2 (Grammatical inversion > fixation)] > [Test 1 (Grammatical inversion > fixation)]

Author: Finn
Citation: Finn, A. S., Hudson Kam, C. L., Ettlinger, M., Vytlacil, J., & D’Esposito, M. (2013). Learning language with the wrong neural scaffolding: The cost of neural commitment to sounds. Frontiers in Systems Neuroscience, 7. https://doi.org/10.3389/fnsys.2013.00085
Contrast Name: [grammatical > implicit baseline] during grammatical judgment for mini-language sentences (this mini-language uses similar phonology to L1-EnGish).

Author: Finn
Citation: Finn, A. S., Hudson Kam, C. L., Ettlinger, M., Vytlacil, J., & D’Esposito, M. (2013). Learning language with the wrong neural scaffolding: The cost of neural commitment to sounds. Frontiers in Systems Neuroscience, 7. https://doi.org/10.3389/fnsys.2013.00085
Contrast Name: [grammatical > implicit baseline] during grammatical judgment for mini-language sentences (this mini-language uses dissimilar phonology to L1-EnGish).

Author: Fletcher
Citation: Fletcher, P., Büchel, C., Josephs, O., Friston, K., & Dolan, R. (1999). Learning-related neuronal responses in prefrontal cortex studied with functional neuroimaging. Cerebral Cortex (New York, N.Y.: 1991), 9(2), 168–178. https://doi.org/10.1093/cercor/9.2.168
Contrast Name: Consonant-string classification v. sensorimotor task control collapsed over 6 blocks

Author: Fletcher
Citation: Fletcher, P., Büchel, C., Josephs, O., Friston, K., & Dolan, R. (1999). Learning-related neuronal responses in prefrontal cortex studied with functional neuroimaging. Cerebral Cortex (New York, N.Y.: 1991), 9(2), 168–178. https://doi.org/10.1093/cercor/9.2.168
Contrast Name: Increasing activation across all blocks for [Consonant-string classification v. sensorimotor task control]; 6 blocks of 10 items (50% grammatical) each repeated 6 times with immediate feedback; thus, this is activity related to implicitly learning grammaticality rules that applied to novel stimuli in each subsequent block.

Author: Forkstam
Citation: Forkstam, C., Hagoort, P., Fernandez, G., Ingvar, M., & Petersson, K. M. (2006). Neural correlates of artificial syntactic structure classification. NeuroImage, 32(2), 956–967. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.neuroimage.2006.03.057
Contrast Name: [grammaticality judgment] > [is it a string of P's or L's] across both days 1 and 8

Author: Forkstam
Citation: Forkstam, C., Hagoort, P., Fernandez, G., Ingvar, M., & Petersson, K. M. (2006). Neural correlates of artificial syntactic structure classification. NeuroImage, 32(2), 956–967. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.neuroimage.2006.03.057
Contrast Name: Day 1 only: [grammatical > ungrammatical] balanced for chunk strength

Author: Forkstam
Citation: Forkstam, C., Hagoort, P., Fernandez, G., Ingvar, M., & Petersson, K. M. (2006). Neural correlates of artificial syntactic structure classification. NeuroImage, 32(2), 956–967. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.neuroimage.2006.03.057
Contrast Name: Day 8 only: [grammatical > ungrammatical] balanced for chunk strength

Author: Forkstam
Citation: Forkstam, C., Hagoort, P., Fernandez, G., Ingvar, M., & Petersson, K. M. (2006). Neural correlates of artificial syntactic structure classification. NeuroImage, 32(2), 956–967. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.neuroimage.2006.03.057
Contrast Name: [grammatical] > [ungrammatical] on day 8

Author: Goranskaya
Citation: Goranskaya, D., Kreitewolf, J., Mueller, J. L., Friederici, A. D., & Hartwigsen, G. (2016). Fronto-parietal contributions to phonological processes in successful artificial grammar learning. Frontiers in Human Neuroscience, 10. https://doi.org/10.3389/fnhum.2016.00551
Contrast Name: Learn + Test > Baseline

Author: Hauser
Citation: Hauser, M. F. A., Hofmann, J., & Opitz, B. (2012). Rule and similarity in grammar: Their interplay and individual differences in the brain. NeuroImage, 60(4), 2019–2026. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.neuroimage.2012.02.016
Contrast Name: [Viewing grammatical sentences of pseudowords] > [Viewing ungrammatical sentences of pseudowords] during grammaticality judgement task.`
